articles.headline: As Trade Deficit Grows, So Do Tensions With China
articles.snippet: With the United States reporting on Thursday yet another surge in its trade deficits with China and the rest of the world, economic tensions are rising again as Washington prepares for the long-delayed visit of President Hu Jintao late next month....
articles.abstract: With the United States reporting on Thursday yet another surge in its trade deficits with China and the rest of the world, economic tensions are rising again as Washington prepares for the long-delayed visit of President Hu Jintao late next month.     But international trade rules and a tight Congressional calendar are limiting the options of American politicians and trade negotiators, who are under increasing pressure to find some way to curb the growth in China's exports.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, March 9 - With the United States reporting on Thursday yet another surge in its trade deficits with China and the rest of the world, economic tensions are rising again as Washington prepares for the long-delayed visit of President Hu Jintao late next month.

articles.headline: Changing U.S. Audience Poses Test for a Giant of Spanish TV
articles.snippet: Rosa Guevara, a Mexican-American dental hygienist, grew up with the Univision network's Spanish-language soap operas, which she still watches. But Mrs. Guevara, 59, now watches alone.      On any given night, her husband is glued to a western on c...
articles.abstract: Rosa Guevara, a Mexican-American dental hygienist, grew up with the Univision network's Spanish-language soap operas, which she still watches. But Mrs. Guevara, 59, now watches alone.      On any given night, her husband is glued to a western on cable while her 25-year-old daughter who used to watch the soaps with her, may tune in to ''George Lopez'' on ABC or syndicated reruns of ''Friends.''
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, March 9 - Rosa Guevara, a Mexican-American dental hygienist, grew up with the Univision network's Spanish-language soap operas, which she still watches. But Mrs. Guevara, 59, now watches alone.

articles.headline: SAT Errors Raise New Qualms About Testing
articles.snippet: The scoring errors disclosed this week on thousands of the College Board's SAT tests were made by a company that is one of the largest players in the exploding standardized testing business, handling millions of tests each year.     The mistakes, ...
articles.abstract: The scoring errors disclosed this week on thousands of the College Board's SAT tests were made by a company that is one of the largest players in the exploding standardized testing business, handling millions of tests each year.     The mistakes, which the company, Pearson Educational Measurement, acknowledged yesterday, raised fresh questions about the reliability of the kinds of high-stakes tests that increasingly dominate education at all levels. Neither Pearson, which handles state testing across the country, nor the College Board detected the scoring problems until two students came forward with complaints.
articles.lead_paragraph: The scoring errors disclosed this week on thousands of the College Board's SAT tests were made by a company that is one of the largest players in the exploding standardized testing business, handling millions of tests each year.
articles.byline: By Karen W. Arenson and Diana B. Henriques

articles.headline: In Phoenix, Even Cactuses Wilt in Clutches of Record Drought
articles.snippet: Thursday began like the 141 days before it, sunny and crisp, dust settling everywhere except on the record -- set again -- for the number of days without rain.      Phoenix knows all about dry weather. It is a place where children are drilled thro...
articles.abstract: Thursday began like the 141 days before it, sunny and crisp, dust settling everywhere except on the record -- set again -- for the number of days without rain.      Phoenix knows all about dry weather. It is a place where children are drilled throughout elementary school to conserve water, where hotels boast of covered parking areas not to protect from rain, but to offer a bit of shade. Grown men spread lotion all over their bodies every morning. Noses bleed. Newcomers watch in horror as their hands seem to age right in front of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX, March 9 - Thursday began like the 141 days before it, sunny and crisp, dust settling everywhere except on the record -- set again -- for the number of days without rain.

articles.headline: Under Pressure, Dubai Company Drops Port Deal
articles.snippet: The state-owned Dubai company seeking to manage some terminal operations at six American ports dropped out of the deal on Thursday, bowing to an unrelenting bipartisan attack in Congress that swept aside President Bush's efforts.     The company, ...
articles.abstract: The state-owned Dubai company seeking to manage some terminal operations at six American ports dropped out of the deal on Thursday, bowing to an unrelenting bipartisan attack in Congress that swept aside President Bush's efforts.     The company, DP World, said that at the direction of Dubai's ruler it would ''transfer'' to a still-unnamed American company the leases to manage some of the busiest terminals in the United States, including some in New York, Newark, Baltimore and Miami.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 9 - The state-owned Dubai company seeking to manage some terminal operations at six American ports dropped out of the deal on Thursday, bowing to an unrelenting bipartisan attack in Congress that swept aside President Bush's efforts.

articles.headline: Dubai Deal's Collapse PromptsFears Abroad on Trade With U.S.
articles.snippet: DP World's decision yesterday to transfer a handful of American port terminals, rather than chilling interest in investing in the United States, may actually have made it safer for foreigners by relieving some of the political pressure that was bu...
articles.abstract: DP World's decision yesterday to transfer a handful of American port terminals, rather than chilling interest in investing in the United States, may actually have made it safer for foreigners by relieving some of the political pressure that was building up against them.     But as part of a pattern of other antiforeign actions in Washington, fears remain that the United States is becoming a less welcoming place for investment from overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: DP World's decision yesterday to transfer a handful of American port terminals, rather than chilling interest in investing in the United States, may actually have made it safer for foreigners by relieving some of the political pressure that was building up against them.

articles.headline: Amazon Considering Downloads
articles.snippet: Amazon.com is in talks with three Hollywood studios about starting a service that would allow consumers to download movies and TV shows for a fee and burn them onto DVD's, according to three people briefed on the discussions.     If the advanced n...
articles.abstract: Amazon.com is in talks with three Hollywood studios about starting a service that would allow consumers to download movies and TV shows for a fee and burn them onto DVD's, according to three people briefed on the discussions.     If the advanced negotiations are successfully concluded, Amazon's service would position itself in the media world alongside rivals like Apple Computer's iTunes as a place where people go not just to order goods to be sent by mail, but to instantly enjoy digital wares as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amazon.com is in talks with three Hollywood studios about starting a service that would allow consumers to download movies and TV shows for a fee and burn them onto DVD's, according to three people briefed on the discussions.

articles.headline: Univision May Have New Suitor
articles.snippet: A consortium of companies and investors that includes the Mexican television giant Grupo Televisa has emerged as a potential bidder for Univision, the largest Spanish-language television and radio company in the United States.     The consortium i...
articles.abstract: A consortium of companies and investors that includes the Mexican television giant Grupo Televisa has emerged as a potential bidder for Univision, the largest Spanish-language television and radio company in the United States.     The consortium includes private equity firms Providence Equity Partners and Madison Dearborn Partners, as well as the Cisneros Group of Venezuela and the media entrepreneur Haim Saban, according to people involved in the group.
articles.lead_paragraph: A consortium of companies and investors that includes the Mexican television giant Grupo Televisa has emerged as a potential bidder for Univision, the largest Spanish-language television and radio company in the United States.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Peter Edmonston

articles.headline: MORE ON PORTS DEAL
articles.snippet: POLITICAL MOVES -- As Dubai's ruler was making up his mind on the ports deal, a rebellion by Congressional Republicans continued to play out in Washington.   PAGE A18    FOREIGN INVESTMENT -- DP World's decision may relieve some of Washington's po...
articles.abstract: POLITICAL MOVES -- As Dubai's ruler was making up his mind on the ports deal, a rebellion by Congressional Republicans continued to play out in Washington.   PAGE A18    FOREIGN INVESTMENT -- DP World's decision may relieve some of Washington's political pressure on foreign companies, but fears remain that the United States is becoming less friendly.   NEWS ANALYSIS, PAGE C1
articles.lead_paragraph: POLITICAL MOVES -- As Dubai's ruler was making up his mind on the ports deal, a rebellion by Congressional Republicans continued to play out in Washington. PAGE A18

articles.headline: Why Not Let Companies Ignore a Law?
articles.snippet: WHEN Christopher Cox, a California congressman, was named to head a bitterly divided Securities and Exchange Commission nine months ago, many doubted that he would be a tough regulator.      This was, after all, a Republican politician who had sup...
articles.abstract: WHEN Christopher Cox, a California congressman, was named to head a bitterly divided Securities and Exchange Commission nine months ago, many doubted that he would be a tough regulator.      This was, after all, a Republican politician who had supported an effort to block accounting rules on stock options.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Christopher Cox, a California congressman, was named to head a bitterly divided Securities and Exchange Commission nine months ago, many doubted that he would be a tough regulator.

articles.headline: After the Fed, Exuberance
articles.snippet: From an airy oval-shaped office with a striking bay window offering a panoramic view of a downtown street here, Alan Greenspan is trying to replicate his long-ago life as a Wall Street economic forecaster. But with a big difference.     After all,...
articles.abstract: From an airy oval-shaped office with a striking bay window offering a panoramic view of a downtown street here, Alan Greenspan is trying to replicate his long-ago life as a Wall Street economic forecaster. But with a big difference.     After all, for the last 18 years as chairman of the Federal Reserve, Mr. Greenspan has exercised a powerful influence on the national and global economy, becoming a celebrity in the process. His return to private life, as a result, has been far from private.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 9 - From an airy oval-shaped office with a striking bay window offering a panoramic view of a downtown street here, Alan Greenspan is trying to replicate his long-ago life as a Wall Street economic forecaster. But with a big difference.
